metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Assessee

facts.text: The assessee is a public limited company carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of yarn.

The assessee held 2,760 shares of Rs. 100 each in Indian Mills Supply Company Private Limited, 1,000 shares of Rs. 100 each in Harveys Private Limited, and 1,800 shares of Rs. 100 each in Pandyan Weaving Mills Private Limited.
The above three companies went into voluntary liquidation in December 1959.

In the course of liquidation proceedings, the liquidators made distribution in the relevant year of account and the assessee company got cash or assets in lieu of cash of Rs. 4,57,858 in respect of Indian Mills Supply Company Private Limited, Rs. 1,41,739 in respect of Harveys Private Limited, and Rs. 1,83,175 in respect of Pandyan Weaving Mills Private Limited.
The matter relates to assessment year 1961-62.

Revenue took the view that by reason of the distribution of assets of the three private companies under liquidation by the liquidators, there had been a capital gain of Rs. 96,735.85 in respect of Indian Mills Supply Company Private Limited and Rs. 41,168.88 in respect of Harveys Private Limited making a total of Rs. 1,37,904.73. Out of that, loss amounting to Rs. 41,960.56 in respect of Pandyan Weaving Mills Private Limited was deducted, leaving a balance of Rs. 95,944.00.

The assessee company at first showed the sum of Rs. 95,944.00 as capital gains but subsequently filed a statement showing a loss of Rs. 59,104 on the basis that the cost of shares distributed by the liquidators should be taken at the figure at which they had been acquired by the companies which distributed the shares.
The Income-tax Officer assessed the assessee company to capital gain at the sum of Rs. 95,944.

Aggrieved by the order of the Income-tax Officer, the assessee filed appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and on being unsuccessful there, filed further appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

The Tribunal held that there was an exchange or transfer of shares and assets in question. The transaction could also be viewed as a relinquishment. The assessee was consequently held liable to pay tax on the sum of Rs. 95,944 under section 12B of the Act.

The question 'Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 95,944/- is liable to tax under Section 12B?' was thereafter, on the application of the assessee, referred to the High Court under section 66 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

Madras High Court answered the question in the negative in favour of the assessee by judgment and order dated February 28, 1969 in Tax Case No. 124 of 1965. The High Court held that when a liquidator distributes the assets of a company which has gone into voluntary liquidation, he is performing a legal function and there is no element of sale, transfer, exchange or relinquishment involved in such distribution.
This appeal on certificate has been filed by the Commissioner of Income Tax against the judgment of Madras High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 95,944/- is liable to tax under Section 12B of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922?

Whether the distribution of assets of the companies which had gone into voluntary liquidation by the liquidators to the assessee company resulted in a transaction which amounted to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer under section 12B(1).

petitioner_arguments.text: The transaction in question amounted to sale or transfer.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 12B of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

petitioner_arguments.text: The omission of distribution of capital assets on liquidation of a company from the first proviso to section 12B(1) as revised by Finance (No. 3) Act of 1956 (as compared to third proviso in earlier enactment) shows legislative intent to treat such distribution as sale, exchange or transfer.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 12B proviso, Income Tax and Excess Profit Tax Amendment Act, 1947; Finance (No. 3) Act, 1956

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 46 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 contains a provision for charging capital gains on money or assets received by shareholder on liquidation, implying similar liability under 1922 Act.

respondent_arguments.text: The transaction in question involved no sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer and as such, the amount in question was not capital gain under section 12B of the Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 12B of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

court_reasoning.text: The act of each of the liquidators in distributing the assets of the company which had gone into voluntary liquidation did not result in the creation of new rights. It merely entailed recognition of legal rights which were in existence prior to the distribution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Liquidator is only a trustee; property passes into his custody to be applied as directed by statute.

court_reasoning.text: When a shareholder receives money representing his share on distribution of the net assets of the company in liquidation, he receives that money in satisfaction of the right which belonged to him by virtue of his holding the shares and not by operation of any transaction which amounts to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No beneficial interest passes in the property conveyed or transferred.

court_reasoning.text: The omission in the proviso does not change the character of the transaction; provisos are often inserted to allay fears and cannot enlarge the scope of the enactment or override plain words.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Language of section 12B(1) does not cover such distribution.

court_reasoning.text: Distribution of assets by liquidator on voluntary winding up cannot constitute sale, transfer or exchange for purposes of section 12B(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee not liable to pay tax on capital gains under section 12B in respect of Rs. 95,944.

holdings.text: Distribution of the assets of the companies in liquidation does not amount to a transaction of sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer so as to attract section 12B of the Act.
The assessee company is not liable to pay tax on capital gains as contemplated by section 12B of the Act in respect of the amount of Rs. 95,944.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax U.P. v. Bankey Lal Vaidya
precedents_cited.relevance: Distribution of partnership assets on dissolution is not sale, exchange or transfer; analogous to liquidation distribution.

precedents_cited.case_name: James Anderson v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Involved actual sale of shares by attorney, not distribution; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Dewas Cine Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Allotment of partnership assets on dissolution is not sale or transfer for a price.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Associated Industrial Development Co. P. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Amount received by shareholder on liquidation not assessable as capital gains; no sale etc.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. R. M. Amin

precedents_cited.relevance: Liquidator in voluntary winding up in position of trustee for members when distributing surplus assets.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 12B charges capital gains on sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer of capital asset; distribution by liquidator not covered. Section 66 for reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax and Excess Profit Tax Amendment Act, 1947 (Act 22 of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced capital gains tax; third proviso clarified certain distributions not treated as sale etc.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Finance Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished capital gains tax except for gains before April 1, 1948.

statutes_cited.name: Finance (No. 3) Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Revived capital gains tax from April 1, 1957; first proviso omitted certain clarifications.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Expressly charges capital gains on liquidation distribution; does not imply liability under 1922 Act.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal filed by the Commissioner of Income Tax, upholding the Madras High Court's decision that the sum of Rs. 95,944 is not liable to tax under Section 12B as the distribution by liquidators does not constitute sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer.
outcome.relief_granted: Assessee not liable to capital gains tax on Rs. 95,944
